content:
• Thursday, April 3, 2014
  • HXM

    Homex in talks with Zell Credit to provide financing, +15.8% AH

    • Homex Development (NYSE:HXM) +15.8% AH after disclosing it is in discussions with an affiliate of Zell Credit Opportunities Fund to obtain secured financing to fund construction of more than 8K new homes in Mexico and general corporate activities.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:40 PM
  • NMBL

    Nimble Storage +2.2% AH following Piper coverage launch

    • Piper has launched coverage on Nimble Storage (NYSE:NMBL) with an Overweight and $50 PT.
    • Shares fell 11.3% in regular trading as part of a general rout in high-beta enterprise tech names. They're down 41% from a Feb. 28 high of $58, but still up 64% from a $21 December IPO price.
    • Nimble's lockup expiration arrives on June 11.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:44 PM

  • After hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: SNX +14.3%. ALGN +4.9%. SEAC +4.1%. DYAX +3.6%. ENVI +3.5%.
    • Top losers, as of 5:15 p.m.: SGMO -10.4%. OPTT -6.6%. CYCC -5.4%. WMC -4.0%. GPN -2.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:38 PM | 3 Comments
  • SNX

    Synnex +13.8% AH on FQ1 beat, strong guidance

    • Synnex (NYSE:SNX) expects FQ2 revenue of $3.1B-$3.2B and EPS of $1.34-$1.38, easily above a consensus of $3.01B and $1.14.
    • Technology Solutions (IT product distribution) sales jumped 20% Y/Y in FQ1 to $2.9B, and the division's adjusted op. income rose 19% to $63.5M. The Concentrix services division, which received a $74.5M contribution from the customer care outsourcing business Synnex just bought from IBM, had revenue of $127M and op. income of $11.8M.
    • Op. margin fell 22 bps Y/Y to 2.05%. Synnex ended FQ1 with $162.4M in cash/investments, and $762.6M in borrowings.
    • FQ1 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:35 PM
  • MRCY

    Reuters: Boeing explores purchase of Mercury Systems

    • Mercury Systems (NASDAQ:MRCY) +8.6% AH on a Reuters report that says Boeing (NYSE:BA) is considering buying the supplier of digital signal and image processing systems to the aerospace and defense industry.
    • A Boeing acquisition of one of its suppliers would allow it to save costs and increase its footprint in commercial aerospace components, and would allow it to gain access to MRCY's microprocessor business, which can be used on unmanned aerial vehicles.
    • MRCY is said to be seeking ~$500M in a sale.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:26 PM
  • AWSM

    InfoSonics bucks tech selloff after launching $139 Android phone

    • InfoSonics' (IFON +2.8%) s450/Onyx Android phone has unmistakably low-end/mid-range specs: The phone sports a 4.5" 845x480 display, dual-core 1.2GHz. CPU, 2G/3G radio, 8MP camera, and just 4GB of internal memory.
    • But given its price tag, the s450 could fare well in some of the emerging market InfoSonics targets. Rising demand for low-end Android phones in emerging markets led InfoSonics Q4 sales to rise 40% Y/Y; the company faces stiff competition from Huawei, ZTE, and a slew of other Asian OEMs and white-label manufacturers.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:22 PM
  • OPTT

    Ocean Power announces stock offering, shares -5.5% AH

    • Ocean Power Technologies (NASDAQ:OPTT) -5.5% AH after announcing a proposed public offering of common stock; the company does not give an amount.
    • OPTT plans to use proceeds to acquire or invest in complementary products or toward any combination of working capital, capital expenditures, and general business purposes, including additional development, testing and demonstrations of its PowerBuoy systems.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:43 PM | 1 Comment
  • MU

    Micron Technology beats by $0.09, beats on revenue

    • Micron Technology (NASDAQ:MU): Q2 EPS of $0.85 beats by $0.09.
    • Revenue of $4.10B (+97.1% Y/Y) beats by $110M.
    • Shares +3.1% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:11 PM | 12 Comments
  • RPM

    RPM pushes to all-time highs after strong quarter

    • RPM International (RPM +5.2%) shares hit all-time highs after swinging to a profit in its FQ3 results, as improved revenue in its industrial segments helped offset the effect of severe weather on its consumer business.
    • RPM raised its FY 2014 EPS outlook to $2.10-$2.15 from $2.05-$2.10, vs. $2.11 analyst consensus, and forecast 2014 industrial sales growth of 4%-6% and consumer sales growth of 8%-10%, citing stronger than anticipated leverage in its industrial segment resulting from solid performance in Europe and businesses serving U.S. construction markets.
    • RPM's strategically balanced business model "continues to serve us well in these choppy economic times," CEO Frank Sullivan says.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM | 1 Comment
  • NOW

    Enterprise tech momentum plays have an ugly day

    • Today's rout in tech momentum names (the latest in a string) has been especially harsh on enterprise cloud software, security, and big data/analytics plays.
    • Major cloud software decliners: NOW -11%. WDAY -9.6%. N -6.5%. CNQR -7.2%. SAAS -6.3%. TXTR -6.3%. ULTI -5.5%. DWRE -8%. MKTO -6.2%. CSLT -9%. RALY -7.2%.
    • Salesforce (CRM -4.1%) is following the group lower after announcing plans to offer industry-specific cloud software solutions. Pac Crest thinks Salesforce's top-line will benefit, but is cutting its EPS estimates on margin concerns.
    • Security decliners: FEYE -10.3%. PANW -8.2%. KEYW -5.7%.
    • Big data/analytics decliners: DATA -7.4%. SPLK -6.9%. QLIK -4.1%. Splunk's selloff comes in spite of a two-notch CLSA upgrade to Outperform.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:57 PM | 10 Comments
  • GNW

    Report: Genworth set to launch IPO of Aussie M/I unit

    • Down about 2% earlier, Genworth (GNW +0.3%) moves into the green as the Australian Financial Review reports the company is set to move forward with an $800M IPO of its Australian mortgage insurance unit. Pre-marketing research, says the AFR, could hit fund managers' desks as early as Monday.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:49 PM
  • BOFI

    BofI targeted by Kerrisdale Capital

    • A difficult March continues for highflier BofI Holding (BOFI -3.3%) after the online bank is reportedly highlighted as a top short pick by Kerrisdale Capital at the Value Investing Conference.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:26 PM | 2 Comments
  • APC

    Confirmed: Anadarko settles Tronox cleanup case for $5.15B

    • Anadarko (APC +12.1%) confirms it has entered into a settlement with the plaintiffs in the Tronox (TROX +1.6%) case to resolve all claims against Kerr-McGee, agreeing to pay $5.15B to settle environmental claims left behind when it bought the company for $18B in 2005.
    • APC expects to record a gross tax benefit of ~$1.65B associated with the settlement, offset by ~$1.1B in uncertain tax positions, resulting in a net tax benefit of ~$550M.
    • The U.S. had initially sought $25B from APC to clean up 2,772 sites and compensate ~8,100 TROX claimants, and a court in December said APC could expect to pay damages as low as $5.2B and as high as $14.2B.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:40 PM | 2 Comments
  • CF

    CF Industries downgraded at Citi on valuation, lack of near-term catalysts

    • CF Industries (CF -2%) is downgraded to Neutral from Buy at Citigroup, which cites valuation and a lack of near-term catalysts for the stock as the market already has rewarded management moves to deploy more capital to shareholders, sell phosphate asses, and position the company as a fist mover in adding new capacity through 2016.
    • Although seeing potential for $27-plus of EPS in 2016 thanks in part to the new capacity, the firm says risks remain for CF, including a softer urea market in H2 of this year, as China’s exports increase and grain prices may fall in the face of record crops.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:26 PM | 2 Comments
  • APC

    Report: EPA, DoJ set to announce Anadarko settlement of Tronox claims

    • Anadarko Petroleum (APC +9.2%) shares surge on a report that the EPA and Justice Department will announce a settlement today related to liabilities in the Tronox case.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:54 PM | 1 Comment
  • SCHW

    Online brokers tumble; Schwab decries HFT

    • "High-frequency trading is a growing cancer that needs to be addressed," writes Schwab (SCHW -0.5%) CEO Walt Bettinger. HFT "has run amok and is corrupting our capital market system by creating an unleveled playing field for individual investors and driving the wrong incentives for our commodity and equities exchanges. ... Trade orders from individual investors are now pawns in a bigger chess game."
    • It's hard to make the connection between HFT and the online brokers, but they're tumbling in wake of Bettinger's essay. E-Trade (ETFC -6.3%), TD Ameritrade (AMTD -3.6%)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:36 PM | 11 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Top 10 Gainers: OTC:RGDX +22%. IMMY-OLD +11%. JRJC +10%. IPWR +9%. ISR +7%. CPRX +7%. AMRS +7%. GST +6%. AUO +6%. PLCC +6%.
    • Top 10 Losers: SGOC -28%. OTC:BGMD -18%. DLHC -18%. BKS -13%. LQDT -12%. OTCPK:MKTY -12%. BWEN -12%. APPY -11%. OPTT -10%. KIN -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM
  • LNG

    Enel close to 20-year deal to buy natural gas from Cheniere

    • Cheniere Energy (LNG -1.7%) reportedly is close to securing its second large supply deal this week, as it nears a 20-year deal with Italian utility Enel (OTCPK:ENLAY) for 1B cubic meters/year of gas.
    • Earlier this week, LNG signed a 20-year supply deal with Spanish utility Endesa for gas from its proposed Corpus Christi plant in Texas.
    • LNG already has secured several sales deals from its Sabine Pass export plant in Louisiana and is now focusing on locking in customers for the Texas plant, even though U.S. regulators have not yet approved that site for exports.
    • Shares may be lower today because of a Credit Suisse downgrade to Neutral from Outperform, as LNG has climbed ~35% in two months and many of the company's near-term positives have been priced in.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:37 PM | 2 Comments
  • RAD

    Rite Aid records higher March same-store sales, shares +2.6%

    • Rite Aid (RAD +2.6%) joins Walgreen (WAG +0.8%) in reporting higher same-store sales for March; RAD says same-store sales climbed 0.7% and pharmacy comps rose 3.5% helped by a 1.1% increase in prescriptions, but front-end sales slipped 5% due in part to a late Easter.
    • Alan Stacy's calculation shows total drugstore sales for the month, which rose 0.4% to $1.95B, would have increased by 1.7% if Easter had fallen in March.
    • Earlier: Walgreen comp sales up 3.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:59 AM | 1 Comment
  • ACTG

    Acacia gains on patent deals with Motorola Mobility, Huawei

    • Acacia (ACTG +4%) has settled its patent disputes with Motorola Mobility (soon to be owned by Lenovo) and Chinese IT/telecom equipment giant Huawei, and reached licensing agreements with both firms.
    • The company also says a suit against private BRS Labs related to security video analytics patents has been dismissed.
    • Previous: Acacia settles three patent cases
     
     
     
     
    | 11:41 AM
  • TEDU

    Chinese IT education firm Tarena higher after IPO

    • Tarena (NASDAQ:TEDU) opened for trading at $9.86 and has quickly risen to $10.42, up 15.8% from a $9 IPO price. The provider of Chinese IT education services has a market cap of $528M, or 5.7x trailing sales.
    • Tarena had 2013 revenue of $92.8M (+63% Y/Y), and net income of $14M.
    • Prospectus, IPO preview
     
     
     
     
    | 11:02 AM
  • GG

    Goldcorp extends bid deadline for Osisko, will study Yamana proposal

    • Goldcorp (GG -1.5%), whose C$2.6B hostile bid for Osisko Mining (OSKFF -1.7%) was set to expire this Friday, says it is extending its offer until April 15 while it continues its due diligence process at Osisko’s Malartic mine in Quebec.
    • In an attempt to thwart Goldcorp's offer, Osisko said Yamana Gold (AUY -1.5%) would buy a 50% stake in its mining and exploration assets for C$930M, and GG says it plans to complete an analysis of yesterday's proposal.
    • GG agreed last month not to take up and pay for shares that were deposited in favor of its bid before April 15, as part of a settlement with Osisko.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:57 AM | 6 Comments
  • APO

    More on bullish new coverage of P-E names

    • Acknowledging the Street is already way long the stocks, Bernstein nevertheless starts coverage of Apollo Global (NYSE:APO), Blackstone (NYSE:BX), and KKR with Outperform ratings, noting P/E multiples of 11x for alternatives is way below that of traditional asset managers at 16x (a fact also noted by Blackstone's Stephen Schwarzman).
    • At current valuations, says analyst Luke Montgomery, investors are paying only for cash flows from existing funds and get the going-concern value and any positives from yet-to-be-launched funds for free. "More important, they get a free option on the significant growth opportunities we see for these firms."
    • “Their advantage is extremely difficult to replicate, which means these firms have a large halo effect and are operating in a league of their own with little competition in their path. Meanwhile, the larger scale of these firms is generating outsized cash flow that is supporting a push into higher growth, less scale-constrained strategies, like credit and real estate."
    • Apollo is Montgomery's "Credit Growth Play," while Blackstone is "The Innovation as Cycle Muting Play," and KKR is "The Economies of Skill Play." If he had to pick from among the three, it would be KKR given valuation and its differentiated strategy.
    • Previously: Positive P-E sector coverage launched at Bernstein
    • Related ETFs: PSP, PEX
     
     
     
     
    | 10:54 AM | 5 Comments
  • GOOG

    Google rallies following "split;" voting shares given slight premium

    • Both Google's new non-voting class C shares (GOOG +2.5%) and voting class A shares (GOOGL +2.6%) are posting solid gains. However, the latter are trading at a ~$1.40 premium to the former.
    • By allowing Google to issue non-voting shares that don't dilute Larry Page, Sergey Brin, and Eric Schmidt's voting rights, the split could make the Web giant more willing to use equity for major acquisitions.
    • Facebook, which already has a dual-class share structure that leaves Mark Zuckerberg in firm control, is set to issue over $17B worth of shares to acquire WhatsApp and Oculus VR.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:42 AM | 9 Comments
  • GBX

    Greenbier -2.2% as earnings rise but miss estimates

    • Greenbrier (GBX -2.2%) reports its FQ2 earnings rose 13% on double-digit increases in revenue at its manufacturing and wheels, repair and parts segments, but shares are lower as results failed to meet Wall Street expectations.
    • GBX says severe weather and manufacturing line changeovers at a facility in Oregon weighed on resulted, but manufacturing margins should improve in H2.
    • GBX reports 3,400 new railcar deliveries in the quarter, down 8.1% Q/Q; new railcar manufacturing backlog was 15,200 units valued at ~$1.54B at quarter's end, vs. 13,500 units valued at $1.43B as of Nov. 28.
    • Expects to continue to expand tank car and retrofit capacity and capabilities, and will certify its largest repair facility in Cleburne, Tex., to perform tank car work.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:29 AM
  • Z

    Zillow higher after deal with China's E-House; Trulia also up

    • Looking to target Chinese investors pouring billions into U.S. real estate, Zillow (Z +1%) is partnering with E-House's (EJ -0.9%) Leju unit to create a co-branded website for Leju visitors searching for U.S. properties.
    • The site launches in early summer, and will provide access to Zillow's listings, search platform, and home data. The companies note Chinese buyers spent an estimated $11B on U.S. homes in the 12 months ending March 2013, with an average purchase price of $425K.
    • Zillow is trading higher, as is rival Trulia (TRLA +2.4%). The announcement comes four weeks after Leju filed for an IPO, and two weeks after Tencent agreed to buy a 15% stake.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:20 AM | 1 Comment
  • NNN

    National Retail Properties cut to Sell at UBS

    • National Retail Properties (NNN -1.8%) is lower in morning action after UBS downgrades the stock to a Sell with price target reduced to $30 from $33.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:12 AM | 2 Comments
  • LQDT

    Liquidity Services continues plunge after losing rolling stock contract

    • A day after announcing it's the apparent high bidder for the DoD's non-rolling stock surplus contract (albeit with a bid that disappointed investors), Liquidity Services (LQDT -9.2%) says it withdrew from bidding for the DoD's rolling stock surplus contract after it reached a level the company "determined would be economically unsustainable," and would jeopardize its service quality.
    • Liquidity notes the rolling stock contract has historically accounted for 30%-35% of its GMV, and that the terms of its new non-rolling stock contract (price raised from 1.8% of original acquisition value to 4.35%) will yield a "significantly higher cost of goods sold" going forward. As a result, a "material reset" of the company's FY15 (ends Sep. '15) EBITDA forecast will be needed.
    • Shares are now down 26% from Monday's close, and close to their 52-week low of $18. Baird hard downgraded Liquidity to Neutral.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:51 AM
  • BKS

    Barnes & Noble -10% as Liberty plans to cut stake, drop board seats

    • Barnes & Noble (BKS -10.2%) plunges at the open after Liberty Media (LMCA -0.1%) says it is selling the majority of its stake in the bookseller.
    • LMCA will retain a 10% stake to allow BKS "greater flexibility" to right itself and will give up its right to have two representatives on the BKS board.
    • In 2011, LMCA purchased a 17% stake in BKS, which has struggled to compete in a market increasingly dominated by mobile devices and downloadable data.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:49 AM
  • BGMD

    BG prices offering

    • Shares of BG Medicine (OTC:BGMD -18.7%) are down in early trading in response to its public offering of 6,452,000 common shares at $1.55/share. Net proceeds will be $8.9M.
    • Underwriters over-allotment is 967,800 shares.
    • Proceeds will be used to advance the commercialization of its cardiovascular diagnostic tests, CAPEX, IP licensing, debt repayment and working capital.
    • Closing date is April 8.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:44 AM | 1 Comment
  • OPEN

    Tech ratings changes: OpenTable, Level 3, Altera, Xilinx, Telus

    • OpenTable (OPEN +3.2%) has been upgraded to Buy by Citi.
    • Level 3 (LVLT -1.3%) has been cut to Hold by Gabelli.
    • Altera (ALTR +1.2%) and Xilinx (XLNX +0.8%) have been started at Outperform by FBR. Separately, Piper has assumed coverage of Altera at Overweight, and Xilinx at Neutral.
    • Telus (TU -1.2%) has been cut to Neutral by Macquarie. The carrier recently announced a CEO change.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:36 AM
  • P

    Pandora +3.5% premarket following March audience metrics

    • Pandora's (NYSE:P) listener hours rose 14% Y/Y in March to 1.71B. That growth rate is above February's 9% and January's 13%.
    • On the other hand, active listeners were flat M/M at 75.3M. They were up 8% Y/Y vs. 11% in February.
    • Pandora's U.S. radio listening share rose to 9.11% from 8.91% in February and 8.05% a year ago.
    • As previously announced, the company will stop providing monthly audience metrics following its May report. Quarterly numbers will still be posted.
    • Shares have fallen over 20% since the February metrics were released.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:16 AM | 14 Comments

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: AMRS +14%. CYTR +10%. MNGA +7%. CPRX +7%. CTRP +5%.
    • Losers: SGOC -32%. OTC:BGMD -18%. LQDT -13%. APPY -12%. BKS -9%. PBR-A -6%. VVUS -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:09 AM
  • LKM

    NQ Mobile +3.5% premarket after announcing earnings date

    • NQ Mobile's delayed Q4 report will arrive after the close on April 10.
    • Investors are still waiting for the findings of a special audit report on Muddy Waters' fraud allegations to be released.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:06 AM | 2 Comments
  • NWBO

    Northwest: FDA hasn't agreed main endpoint for DCVax trial

    • The Street's Adam Feuerstein, who's having a bit of a running battle with Northwest Biotherapeutics (OTCQB:NWBO), digs deep into the company's 10-K annual report and finds that it hasn't agreed on a main target with the FDA for the Phase III trial of its brain-cancer vaccine DCVax.
    • Northwest wants the primary endpoint to be progression-free survival, but two other companies - ImmunoCellular Therapeutics and Celldex Therapeutics - have been using overall survival as the main goals of their trials for brain-cancer vaccines.
    • Northwest's shares are -3.1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:06 AM | 42 Comments
  • PEIX

    Pacific Ethanol prices 1.75M-share offering at $16, shares -4%

    • Pacific Ethanol (NASDAQ:PEIX) -4% premarket after announcing a public offering of 1.75M common shares priced at $16/share.
    • PEIX plans to use the proceeds to pay outstanding principal and accrued and unpaid interest owed under the terms of its senior unsecured notes, with the remainder going to general corporate purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:51 AM | 6 Comments
  • CYTR

    CytRx shares pop premarket

    • Shares of CytRx (NASDAQ:CYTR) are up 7% before the open on 49K shares in response to an aldoxorubicin study. In a preclinical trial, the drug increased survival 2.5 times greater than doxorubicin in an ex vivo xenograft glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) tumor model in mouse brains.
    • Aldoxorubicin is currently in a Phase 2 clinical trial in late-stage GBM.
    • Late last year, the firm reported positive results from a Phase 2b trial evaluating the drug as a first-line therapy in soft tissue sarcoma.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:32 AM | 1 Comment
  • DCAR

    WPCS up 6.6% after deal to sell Seattle operations

    • EC Company will purchase substantially all of the assets and assume certain liabilities of WPCS International-Seattle for a target sales price of $2.7M.
    • Shares +6.6% premarket
     
     
     
     
    | 8:10 AM

  • Quick gain for euro after ECB stands pat

    • The euro pops 30 pips higher with the ECB leaving policy on hold following plenty of chatter leading up to today's meeting suggesting further stimulus was coming. After the big move up, the euro is flat on the session and buying $1.3775.
    • ECB chief Mario Draghi's press conference beings at 8:30 ET.
    • ETFs: FXE, EUO, ERO, DRR, EUFX, ULE, URR
     
     
     
     
    | 8:04 AM
  • USB

    U.S. Bancorp pulled from Conviction Buy list at Goldman

    • April 3 is officially bank downgrade day, with the latest being U.S. Bancorp (NYSE:USB) being removed from Goldman's Conviction Buy list. It's the 2nd downgrade in 2 days for USB which had its Buy rating pulled at Sandler O'Neill yesterday.
    • Shares -1.3% premarket
    • Q1 earnings seasons starts soon and the outlook is for sluggish results, so it shouldn't be too surprising the sell-side is cashing in a few chips.
    • Earlier: Citi downgraded at Sterne Agee and Deutsche cut at JPMorgan.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:59 AM
  • C

    Citi loses Buy rating at Sterne Agee

    • Citing concerns over controls raised by the Fed when rejecting Citigroup's (NYSE:C) capital return proposal, increasing regulatory risk, slowing earnings growth, and no positive catalysts on the horizon, Sterne Agee  pulls its Buy rating on the name and lowers the price target to $52 from $60.
    • Shares -0.7% premarket
     
     
     
     
    | 7:35 AM
  • DB

    Deutsche loses Buy rating at JPMorgan

    • Deutsche Bank (NYSE:DB) is off 2% premarket after JPMorgan's Kian Abouhossein cashes in what chips he has left on his Buy rating and downgrades to Neutral.
    • Deutsche's down about 15% over the last three months.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:29 AM
  • SNBC

    Sun Bancorp upgraded after new hire

    • Wilbur Ross' hiring of a new CEO for Sun Bancorp (NASDAQ:SNBC) merits an upgrade to the stock at Sterne Agee which boosts the name from Underperform to Neutral. The stock gained 11.2% yesterday on the heels of the hiring of Thomas O'Brien to replace the recently fired Thomas Geisel.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:13 AM

  • European stocks mixed ahead of ECB policy decision

    • As in Asia, shares in Europe are mixed ahead of an ECB policy announcement later today, when the central bank is expected to keep interest rates at 0.25%, although there are some hopes that it could take easing measures to ensure that the eurozone doesn't slip into deflation.
    • Other factors that markets are looking at include a mini-stimulus from China and mixed PMI data.
    • Euro Stoxx 50 +0.1%, London +0.2%, Paris -0.1%, Frankfurt -0.1%, Milan +0.6%, Madrid +0.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:23 AM

  • Asian stocks diverge

    • Asian shares trade mixed, with any positive sentiment coming from China's announcement of a mini-stimulus package to shore up slowing growth, and solid factory orders and ADP jobs data out the U.S. yesterday.
    • Japan +0.8% , Hong Kong +0.2%, China -0.7%, India -0.6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:47 AM
